article:
'BBC Films' is the feature film-making arm of the BBC. It has produced or co-
produced some of the most successful British films of recent years, including
[[An Education]], [[StreetDance 3D]], [[Fish Tank (film)|Fish Tank]], [[Stage
Beauty]], [[A Cock and Bull Story]], [[Nativity! (film)|Nativity!]] and [[Match
Point (film)|Match Point]].

BBC Films co-produces around eight films a year, working in partnership with
major international and UK distributors. Christine Langan is Head of BBC Films,
responsible for the development and production slate, strategy and business
operations.

Recent titles include Nigel Cole's [[Made in Dagenham]], Stephen Frearsâ
[[Tamara Drewe]], Debs Gardner-Patersonâs [[Africa United (2010 film)|Africa
United]], Max and Daniaâs [[StreetDance]], which was Britainâs first-ever
3-D movie.

Until 2007, BBC Films was based in Mortimer Street, near Broadcasting House in
London, while still under the full control of the BBC. A re-structuring of the
division integrated it into the main BBC Fiction department of BBC Vision. As a
result, it moved out of its independent offices into Television Centre, and its
head David M. Thompson left to start his own film production company.
